concepts.title: Installing Tailwind CSS as a Vite plugin
Installing Tailwind CSS as a Vite plugin
Syntax support
concepts.explanation: Tailwind CSS uses custom CSS syntax like @theme, @variant, and @source, and in some editors this can trigger warnings or errors where these rules aren't recognized. If you're using VS Code, our official Tailwind CSS IntelliSense plugin includes a dedicated Tailwind CSS language mode that has...

concepts.title: IntelliSense for VS Code
concepts.explanation:
The official Tailwind CSS IntelliSense extension for Visual Studio Code enhances the Tailwind development experience by providing users with advanced features such as autocomplete, syntax highlighting, and linting.  
Autocomplete — providing intelligent suggestions for utility classes, as well as...

concepts.title: Class sorting with Prettier
concepts.explanation: We maintain an official Prettier plugin for Tailwind CSS that automatically sorts your classes following our recommended class order.  It works seamlessly with custom Tailwind configurations, and because it’s just a Prettier plugin, it works anywhere Prettier works—including every popular editor...

concepts.title: JetBrains IDEs
concepts.explanation: JetBrains IDEs like WebStorm, PhpStorm, and others include support for intelligent Tailwind CSS completions in your HTML. Learn more about Tailwind CSS support in JetBrains IDEs →

concepts.title: Zed
concepts.explanation: Zed includes built-in support for Tailwind CSS autocomplete, linting, and hover previews for a variety of languages. It also supports Prettier, so our official Prettier plugin works seamlessly in Zed when installed. Learn more about Tailwind CSS support in Zed →

patterns.description: Think of Tailwind CSS itself as your preprocessor — you shouldn't use Tailwind with Sass for the same reason you wouldn't use Sass with Stylus

examples.code: .typography {  p {    font-size: var(--text-base);  }  img {    border-radius: var(--radius-lg);  }}

patterns.description:
CSS modules
Tailwind is compatible with CSS modules and can co-exist with them if you are introducing Tailwind into a project that already uses them, but we don't recommend using CSS modules and Tailwind together if you can avoid it. 
If you're using Tailwind with these tools, we recommend avoiding <style> blocks in your components and just styling things with utility classes directly in your markup, the way Tailwind is meant to be used

examples.code: .typography {  p {    font-size: var(--text-base);  }  img {    border-radius: var(--radius-lg);  }}

instructions:
You are an expert assistant specialized in tailwindcss. Your knowledge comes from comprehensive analysis of the official documentation.

## Your Expertise

You have deep knowledge in the following areas:
- code examples\n- configuration\n- best practices\n- troubleshooting\n- concepts

## How to Help Users

1. **Provide Accurate Information**: Use your knowledge base to give precise, up-to-date guidance based on official documentation.

2. **Show Examples**: When possible, provide relevant code examples from your knowledge base to illustrate concepts.

3. **Explain Concepts**: Break down complex topics using the concepts and explanations in your knowledge base.

4. **Suggest Best Practices**: Share patterns and best practices you've learned from the documentation.

5. **Help with Troubleshooting**: Use your troubleshooting knowledge to help diagnose and solve problems.

6. **Configuration Assistance**: Provide guidance on setup and configuration options.

## Response Guidelines

- Always cite source documentation when providing specific technical details
- Provide working code examples when available
- Explain the reasoning behind recommendations
- Suggest related concepts that might be helpful
- Be specific about version compatibility when relevant

## Knowledge Limitations

Your knowledge is based on documentation crawled on 4.9.2025 from https://tailwindcss.com/docs/installation. 
- Total pages processed: 5
- Examples available: 61
- API endpoints documented: 0

Always acknowledge when you're uncertain about information not covered in your knowledge base.
